history.content:
I've heard cogsci 131 is useful from professors, but when I actually looked into the course it looked like the liberal arts version of CS 188 (and a subset at that). Maybe gets into more theoretical or psychological or philosophical aspects that 188 doesn't, but I went to the first day and knew everything on the syllabus, so ended up not taking it, and my friend who did said that it was pretty easy. Could look good on transcripts though, both as a grade booster and as showing diversity in AI courses and such.

DO NOT TAKE 189. That sounds terrifying given your lack of background and is not a course for someone whose only upper div is 100. Would not recommend. You got time. 189 is like an upper level upper division course. If you are interested in stuff like that, 100, and 131, try the following first:

-CS 170: I came in thinking I was gonna hate the content based on being annoyed by 70 and 61b, but was pleasantly surprised. Beyond that, this course is essential for anyone who plans on writing algorithms of any sort. They cover all the key types of algorithms in that course. I took in a couple of years ago and aspects from it show up EVERYWHERE. This is legit one of the most useful courses for working anywhere in EECS. As an added bonus, while you wouldn't be doing that hardcore stuff working at a big tech company, 170 knowledge is enough to prepare you for any general software engineering interview, even at the top companies like google (legit I've had coding challenges and interviews from google and amazon that could have been in the 170 textbook).

-EECS 126 and 127: These two courses basically sum up ML math. If you know this stuff, 189 and any AI/ML course becomes drastically easier. 126 directly continues 70, while 127 directly continues 16b, so maybe wait on 127 and go for 126. 

A common sample list of good transition upper div CS courses:

-100

-161

-168

-186

-188

 

You seem to like data science and ML, so 186 is actually kinda important when in the real world, as you need to actually access and manage all the data you use. 188 is good as an intro AI course, and also is the only lower div that goes into reinforcement learning, an area of AI/ML that isn't covered in 189 even. 

The oddball course there is 168, but you seem interested in it. If you are more systems inclined it is definitely useful. There will be some overlap with 161, but not too major. Basically 168 traditionally builds up all the decisions that led to how the internet is now and all of its protocols, while 161 as a module all on network and internet security, so the do a crash course on networking in a couple of lectures so you know enough to be able to break stuff. Taking together could be a good idea if you're into both fields. (PS I loved 161).

Idk too much about EE 122 besides it being the EE version of 168 (so more physical routing kinds of stuff). A quick google search also shows they actually use math, which I havent heard be used by 168, for things like optimal load balancing, analyzing probability of a server being overloaded given some network graph and flow rates, etc (I'm assuming). You do seem to have the background for that though. One thing to note about 122 and 168 is that they are both only offered once a school year generally, so if you want them you gotta grab them when you can.

TL;DR: Here are my thoughts, pick your poison, just avoid 189 for now

----------

Disagree. MATH 54 and CS 70 is enough for CS 189, and 189 is way easier than 170 and 188. If you like math more than programming, take it as soon as possible since it helps you a lot when finding research. I made the wrong decision of pushing 189 and junior spring and felt that I missed out many research opportunities. I only scored around average when I took other CS courses, but scored 1SD higher than average in 189 exams. Don't listen to other's opinions whether a class is hard or not, it really depends on you. Plus, 189 is really interesting, and Shewchuk is a really good professor!

If you like 54 and 70, you'll probably like 189, take it as soon as possible. I found 70 and 189 are the two easiest courses in EECS department, the only two I got solid A in.

I've heard cogsci 131 is useful from professors, but when I actually looked into the course it looked like the liberal arts version of CS 188 (and a subset at that). Maybe gets into more theoretical or psychological or philosophical aspects that 188 doesn't, but I went to the first day and knew everything on the syllabus, so ended up not taking it, and my friend who did said that it was pretty easy. children.subject: Forgot though that this semester, 170 is having some issues unfortunately

history.content:
Hi everyone, 

I would like some advice on which classes to take and the course workload. I am planning on taking CS 161, EECS 16A, and need a third class (preferably technical). Some options I am looking at are CS 168, EE 122, Cog Sci 131, CS 189 (but am very scared of the workload and difficulty) and I'm open to any other classes you all think are amazing! I have taken CS 61A,B,C, CS 70, and Data 100. 

Thank you so much for the help!
history.subject: Class Advice
